all.definition: The Wagner Act established the National Labor Relations Act (1935), which states that workers have the right to bargain collectively through agents of their choice.
The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) is an agency created by the Wagner Act to oversee labor relations and protect workers' rights to organize.
The Social Security Act (1935) required American workers to pay a social security tax, providing them benefits after reaching 65 years old.
West Coast Hotel v. Parish was a Supreme Court case that upheld a state's right to set minimum wage, overturning the previous ruling in Lochner v. New York.

all.concept: NLRB v. Jones and Laughlin Steel
all.definition: NLRB v. Jones and Laughlin Steel (1937) was a Supreme Court case that confirmed federal jurisdiction over labor relations based on interstate commerce.
The Fair Labor Standards Act (1938) established the 8-hour workday, 40-hour workweek, and federal minimum wage.
The Works Progress Administration (WPA) was a federal agency that financed public work projects during the Great Depression to create employment.
